Award.AwardTitle: The Michigan AGEP Alliance for Transformation (MAA): Mentoring and Community Building to Accelerate Successful Progression into the Professoriate

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Michigan AGEP Alliance for Transformation (MAA) was created in response to the NSF's Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) program solicitation (NSF 12-554) for the AGEP-Transformation (AGEP-T) track. The AGEP-T track targets strategic alliances of institutions and organizations to develop, implement, and study innovative evidence-based models and standards for STEM graduate education, postdoctoral training, and academic STEM career preparation that eliminate or mitigate negative factors and promote positive practices for underrepresented. The Michigan AGEP Alliance for Transformation (MAA): Mentoring and Community Building to Accelerate Successful Progression into the Professoriate represents a collaboration between the University of Michigan, Michigan State University, Michigan Technological University, Wayne State University, and Western Michigan University.

The long-term vision and planned outcome of MAA is to increase the success U.S. citizens who are underrepresented minority (URM) graduate students and postdoctoral scholars in all fields of STEM through graduate study, postdoctoral training and the professoriate. This vision and outcome is being addressed by pursuing the following three overarching goals of the MAA:
1) Adapting two existing models, one for fostering multidisciplinary learning communities with diverse students and the other for improving faculty mentoring of URM graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, to the needs of the five MAA campuses;
2) Studying their effects on the academic identity and career progress of U.S. citizens who are URM graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in STEM programs; and
3) Implementing more widely on campuses those models that lead to improved academic outcomes and widespread institutional change.

The objectives for this project are:
Objective 1: Designing, adapting and implementing evidence-based mentoring initiatives, on all five campuses, that are focused on improved mentoring for U.S. URM graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in all fields of STEM.
Objective 2: Designing, adapting and implementing evidence-based initiatives to promote interdisciplinary learning communities, on all five campuses, that are focused on improved mentoring for U.S. URM STEM graduate students and postdoctoral fellows.
Objective 3: Conducting research about the ways in which improved mentoring and improved sense of community are linked to a sense of academic identity, and the ways in which academic identity is linked to important academic and career outcomes, for U.S. URM graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in all STEM fields.
Objective 4: Conducting research about the ways in which departmental and university variables moderate the relations among mentoring, community, academic identity and academic outcomes for U.S. citizens who are URM graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in all STEM disciplines.

The primary activities that contribute to the model for the alliance include:
1. Designing, adapting and implementing the University of Michigan's Mentoring Others Results in Excellence (MORE) model as a foundation for improving mentoring of U.S. URM graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in STEM. This includes training facilitators who run faculty mentoring workshops, conducting mentoring workshops, training advanced level students for intergenerational mentoring, and developing/distributing individualized mentoring agreements to faculty and STEM programs.
2. Designing, adapting and implementing the Michigan State University's interdisciplinary learning community model as a foundation for improving the sense of belonging, peer support and academic identify of U.S. URM graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in STEM. This includes training facilitators, conducting institution-specific community meetings, and holding MAA-wide community meetings for graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and faculty.

The MAA includes a social science research study that will explore the mechanisms that help explain the under-representation and attrition of URM students in STEM, as well as the contextual and individual factors that can promote academic persistence and success in those fields. The research team predicts that racial/ethnic stigma experiences in students' academic contexts lead to dis-identification from the academic discipline, which then leads to lower academic performance and completion. They also predict that contextual-level resources, such as high-quality mentoring, moderate these relationships. Examples of specific study hypotheses being tested include:
1. Students reporting more negative department diversity climates (stigma experiences) will report lower sense of belonging (affective indicator of academic identity) in their academic departments than students reporting positive diversity climates.
2. Students reporting having higher quality mentoring relationships with their faculty advisors will report more positive academic identity outcomes (higher perceived preparation, higher sense of belonging, higher curricular/professional involvement) than students reporting lower quality mentoring relationships.
3. Quality mentoring will moderate the association between stigma (e.g., reported negative department climate) and academic identity (e.g., reported sense of belonging), such that the negative association of negative department diversity climate with sense of belonging will be stronger for students reporting lower quality mentoring relative to those reporting higher quality mentoring.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was a grant from the Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) program to an Alliance of five Michigan Universities with the University of Michigan (U of M) as lead institution and including Michigan State University (MSU), Wayne State University (WSU), Western Michigan University and Michigan Technological University.  The project had two transformational objectives that centered on the dissemination of two models across the institutions of the Alliance. The Alliance was successful in the dissemination of both models, and in the institutionalization and further development of these transformational initiatives.

The first model emerged from a program at MSU that created an interdisciplinary Learning Community, which was a legacy of previous funding from the National Science Foundation (NSF). The challenge presented to the Alliance was the dissemination of this Learning Community model to the other four institutions of the Alliance, and the nurturing of these communities within the mission and resources of each institution.  The second model focused on the development of research mentoring skills for faculty engaged in guiding the professional development of graduate students from traditionally underrepresented minority (URM) groups; this model had its foundation on the success of an initiative at the lead institution identified as ?Mentoring Others Results in Excellence? (MORE).

MSU took the lead in the dissemination of the Learning Community model, and after the first year of support, AGEP Learning Communities existed in all the Alliance institutions. Although the model had to be adapted to the local features of each institutions, all communities now include regular meetings that provide a venue for students and postdocs to present research results to an audience of their peers that bring to the discussion a broad range of disciplinary foci. The meetings also provide a social network within the institution that connects community members with resources that support their professional development and personal wellness, as they negotiate the challenges of their individual graduate programs. The dissemination of the Learning Community model by MSU used two active approaches:

(1) Members of the MSU leadership team engaged in train-the-trainer activities using visits to the partner institutions as well as the steering committee meetings of the Alliance.

(2) The dissemination plan also used annual multi-institution Fall Conferences hosted by MSU that expanded the local activities of the five Learning Communities to a regional level. 

Beyond the Alliance, MSU has used the Fall Conference to engage academic leaders from minority serving institutions that have a history of collaborations with our institutions. These academic leaders regularly serve as panelists and speakers at the conference and add significantly to the professional network of the students and postdocs of the Alliance.

MSU played a supportive role in the dissemination of the MORE model, which was the contribution of the lead institution to the transformational goals of the project. To that purpose, faculty and administrators of MSU attended train-the trainer sessions at the U of M and used the meetings of the steering committee and the fall conference to share strategies for dissemination. The MORE model is now complemented at MSU by our participation in the National Research Mentoring Network, which is  funded by the National Institutes of Health. To date, eleven tenure-line senior faculty from our institution have received training that covers core competencies for mentoring, including emphasis on the mentoring of URM individuals. Workshops, including sessions targeting members of our Learning Community, are currently offered by the MSU Graduate School and will continue beyond the end of the funding period.

In addition to the transformational objectives of the award, the effort included the implementation of a research plan to determine how the academic experiences of URM students may be different from those of their majority counterparts. For MSU, the data indicate that URM students, compared to non-URM cohorts, see racial and ethnic diversity issues as more important for their academic success. Further, URM students see academic peers as less important than is the case for non-URM respondents. This particular finding may reflect the reality that many URM students in the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) fields are often one of the very few URM students in their departments. The lack of a critical mass of URM students in STEM departments supports the argument for the importance of Learning Communities such as the model offered by MSU and adopted by the institutions of the Alliance.

In summary, the work supported by this award has established Learning Communities and has promoted the importance of research mentoring in all the institutions of the Alliance.  These accomplishments have transformed how these institutions support the preparation of URM students and postdocs for their transition to the professoriate. At MSU, all the core activities initiated by the award have been adopted by the institution and will continue past the period of support.
